climbs.name: Tutankamens Ramen
climbs.fa: M. Geninati, Don Robinson, M. Rangel

content.description: The crux comes several bolts up; look for thin flakes to gaston and pull on to surmount the steep groove.
content.location: Start on right side of wide chimney/gully (C&C Chimney) above the Juniper. Belay from ground and climb blocks to first bolt up high.

content.description: Begin by mounting a block, to base of crack. Protects well and climbs easy til the roof. Punch a #1 camalot below, climb up to a horizontal flake and protect here (plug it into corner will make rope drag badly). Easy to top.
content.protection: standard rack, long sling for under the roof.
content.location: Two dihedrals dominate the rock left of Goodbye Mr. Chips; this is the left of the two. Walk up to a ledge and descend by walking or rappel Trainor Wheels anchor (walk right about 30')

content.description: Easy crack that steepens as you go.
content.location: Right of two prominent dihedrals up and left of big Juniper. Walk up to ledge and start is easy.

content.description: The crux is at the seventh bolt in a small corner. A little spicy to the next clip; it was necessary to bolt it as is.
content.location: On a slab start, SE facing portion of the Confluence Wall. Just right of the corner crack climb.

content.description: Start on 4th Class scramble to a large ledge and clip the first bolt. Go up a slab that steepens to a horizontal crack and work your way right to a nook you can lay in. Nab the corner nubbins to stand and grab the underling. Up big edges from there.
content.location: Walk up left above Goodbye Mr Chips' start to the base of the next few routes. Scramble up and right on easy rock to a large ledge. Easily clip the first bolt.

content.description: This is a mixed route. Start in a hand crack to a ledge. Climb the corner to the start of the roof system. Bolted from there to the top. The crux is pulling through the roof. Rock quality through the roof system ranges from okay to moderately poor. Be aware of your surroundings.
content.location: To the right of Aloof Roof.  Obvious large roof system that extends above a crack/ corner near the center-right of the wall.

content.description: Easy move past first roof/bolt then jugs to the crux move a couple bolts off the ledge. Look for a sidepull way right to make the jugs.
content.location: Start on right side of low roof; right of Goodbye Mr. Chips.

content.description: Perhaps three cruxes; moving past the 4th bolt (probably the hardest move), the 6th bolt, and 8th (last) bolt. Well protected.
content.location: This route is ~10 feet right of Not My Cross to Bear. Starts on a groove/ arete.

climbs.name: Goodbye Mr. Chips
climbs.fa: M. Rangel, Ryan Chamberlain, K. Donohoe

content.description:
Steep start, look for edges near the starting bolt; harder if you are drawn left at the start, really. 

  Crux is higher just past ledge.
content.location: Just right of the prominent arete on the left side of the wall, just past the Juniper and C&C Chimney. At left side of low roof, a slightly overhung start to steep face climbing.

climbs.name: Gimping Ain't Easy
climbs.fa: David A Sampson, Mike Knarzer, Manny Rangel 10/2020

content.description: The finger crack gets difficult just before it widens a few feet off the ground. The crack eases up and then the bolts appear above the ledge. Easy cruising on steep rock and big holds.
content.protection: Standard rack, four bolts and chains.
content.location: This is the third route on the Wall. Just past Black Streak is a finger crack that widens near the ledge midway up then finishes on four bolts.

climbs.name: Frog Drop
climbs.fa: E. Hoffman, M. Geninati, M. Rangel

content.description: Well protected and not too hard.
content.location: Far right side of Confluence Wall is a black streak. This ascends right of that streak on a final line of bolts.

content.description: Good rock, crux near the top.
content.location: Bolted line  to the right of Tutankamens Ramen. Start in a notch, pull a bulge, and face climb a lower angle section to a ledge, and then a slightly overhanging face to the top (exiting left of a roof).

climbs.name: Chips and Dip
climbs.fa: S. Duemler, M. Geninati, M. Rangel

content.description: Left of a black streak for a great hand sized dihedral leading to a bolt off the ledge about 50' above. Continue on good holds and horizontal protection to top and bolted anchor.
content.location: Right side of wall is a black streak. This is just left of the black streak.

content.description: Start right of actual chimney and protect here, traverse up and left on easy rock to chimney, dirt in base so I stemmed around it to the face on the right.
content.location: Left of center in the wall is a large chimney splitting the wall in two. Ascend easier and cleaner rock on right to get into the chimney proper.

climbs.name: Black Streak
climbs.fa: M. Rangel, Eve Hoffman, Lori Wilkerson

content.description: This is on right side of wall, an obvious 10'-15' wide black streak with anchor.
content.location: Right side of Confluence wall on a ledge above the right side of the gorge. A nearly 60' tall black streak of rock has a tough midsection protected by bolts.

content.description: A nice, well protected line that winds around two roofs (and pulls a small roof at the top of the climb), immediately right of Con Five (left of Roof Worthy). Pass a bolt to a ledge, face climb to another ledge. Follow bolts up and through the large roofs to the right of Con Five.
content.location: Look for the large roofs at the top of the crag near the center-right of the wall. Aloof Roof ascends the line that intersects the large roofs near the top of the wall. Beta photo included.

content.description: Couple of short bulges\cruxes interspersed with easier climbing. First is near the start, stick clip helps. Second is passing the ledge above. Scary but ok to clip.
content.location: Just left of Chips and Dip's dihedral on a ledge about 30' above the ground. Anchor belayer on tree at least.

content.description: This East facing wall gets shade in afternoon. It is also just above Christopher Creek, a great place to swim. Most folks know it as the lower exit from the Gorge.
